items.description: The uCIFI LED color light enables to control light colors of a LED luminaire. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

1.title: RGB value
1.description: Text string according to the RBG hexadecimal format with # (e.g. #FF0000 for 100% red).

3436.title: Edge computing manager
3436.description: The uCIFI edge computing manager object defines the capability of a device to run scripts on the device itself. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: false Mandatory: false

1.title: Max number of scripts
1.description: Maximum number of scripts supported by the device.

2.title: Number of free slots for scripts
2.description: Number of free slots to store new scripts.

3.title: Max number of conditions
3.description: Maximum number of conditions supported by the device.

4.title: Number of free slots for conditions
4.description: Number of free slots to store new conditions.

5.title: Edge-computing capabilities
5.description: Vendor-specific resource to share the capabilities of the devices as regards to edge computing.

3437.title: Edge computing script
3437.description: The uCIFI edge computing scripts object defines a particular script to be executed by a device under a time or any other condition set by a "Edge Computing Time Condition" or "Edge Computing Generic Condition" object. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: Edge computing script
items.description: The uCIFI edge computing scripts object defines a particular script to be executed by a device under a time or any other condition set by a "Edge Computing Time Condition" or "Edge Computing Generic Condition" object. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

1.title: Name
1.description: Name of the script.

2.title: Signature
2.description: Unique hash or signature associated to the script to be verified by the end-device before execution. The format of the hash or signature is vendor-specific.

3.title: Version
3.description: Version of the script, as defined by the vendor.

4.title: Script
4.description: Vendor-specific script.

5.title: Script format
5.description: Script format to enable the device to select the script interpreter in case it supports multiple (e.g. LUA). The format of this resource is free to support vendor-specific formats.

6.title: Non supported script
6.description: Set to True if the script is not supported or if the device has identified errors in the script.

7.title: Non authorized script
7.description: Set to True if the hash/signature is not correct.

3438.title: Edge computing time condition
3438.description: The uCIFI edge computing time condition object defines the day/time (defined as a CRON rule) at which a particular script should be executed by a device. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: Edge computing time condition
items.description: The uCIFI edge computing time condition object defines the day/time (defined as a CRON rule) at which a particular script should be executed by a device. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

1.title: Execution time/day
1.description: Date/time at which the script should be executed, formatted as a CRON rule.

2.title: Script identifier
2.description: Object URN/Resource ID of the script to apply to the times/days defined in the execution time/day resource.

3.title: Non supported time condition
3.description: Set to True if the device canâ€™t support the condition.

3439.title: Edge computing generic condition
3439.description: The uCIFI edge computing generic condition object defines a vendor-specific condition (e.g. when a resource or an object is equal to a particular value) at which a particular script should be executed by the device. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: Edge computing generic condition
items.description: The uCIFI edge computing generic condition object defines a vendor-specific condition (e.g. when a resource or an object is equal to a particular value) at which a particular script should be executed by the device. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

1.title: Vendor condition
1.description: Condition described in a vendor specific way.

2.title: Script identifier
2.description: Object URN/Resource ID of the script to apply to the time/days defined in the vendor condition resource.

3.title: Non supported time condition
3.description: Set to True if the device canâ€™t support the condition.

3441.title: LwM2M v1.0 Test Object
3441.description: This object is for use in interoperability tests of the LwM2M v1.0 technical specification. It contains resources for each available datatype. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: LwM2M v1.0 Test Object
items.description: This object is for use in interoperability tests of the LwM2M v1.0 technical specification. It contains resources for each available datatype. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

4.title: Arguments List
4.description: List of Arguments from last execute on "Exec With Arguments"(3) resource. This resource is not affected by the "Randomize values"(1) executable resource.

150.title: Opaque Value
150.description: Initial value must be the bytes sequence "0123456789ABCDEF" (Hexadecimal notation).

160.title: Time Value
160.description: Initial value must be the time to an 1st, 2000 in the UTC time zone. (Timestamp value : 946684800) Unix Time. A signed integer representing the number of seconds since Jan 1 st, 1970 in the UTC time zone.

170.title: ObjLink Value
170.description: Initial value must be a link to instance 0 of Device Object 3 (3:0).

1110.title: Multiple String Value
1110.description: Initial value must be 1 instance with ID 0 and value "initial value".

1120.title: Multiple Integer Value
1120.description: Initial value must be 1 instance with ID 0 and value "1024".

1130.title: Multiple Float Value
1130.description: Initial value must be 1 instance with ID 0 and value "3.14159".

1140.title: Multiple Boolean Value
1140.description: Initial value must be 1 instance with ID 0 and value "true".

1150.title: Multiple Opaque Value
1150.description: Initial value must be 1 instance with ID 0 and value "0123456789ABCDEF"(Hexadecimal notation of the bytes sequence).

1160.title: Multiple Time Value
1160.description: Initial value must be 1 instance with ID 0 and value 1st, 2000 in the UTC time zone (Timestamp value : 946684800). Unix Time. A signed integer representing the number of seconds since Jan 1 st, 1970 in the UTC time zone.

1170.title: Multiple ObjLink Value
1170.description: Initial value must be 1 instance with ID 0 and value "3:0".

3443.title: eSIM IoT
3443.description: The interface between eIM and IPA as described in GSMA SGP.32. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: false Mandatory: false

0.title: State
0.description:
Status
					0  ready to receive eIM message
					1  not able to receive eIM message
					Note: In case value is >0 then writing to resource 2 shall not be possible

1.title: EID
1.description: EID of the eUICC that is target of the object

2.title: eIM message
2.description: The message from eIM to IPA. The message shall be in the ASN.1 DER format defined in SGP.32 Section 6.3.1

3.title: IPA message
3.description: The message from IPA to eIM. The message shall be in the ASN.1 DER format defined in GSMA SGP.32 section 6.3.1

10241.title: HostDeviceInfo
10241.description: This LWM2M Object provides a range of host device related information which can be queried by the LWM2M Server. The host device is any integrated device with an embedded cellular radio module. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: HostDeviceInfo
items.description: This LWM2M Object provides a range of host device related information which can be queried by the LWM2M Server. The host device is any integrated device with an embedded cellular radio module. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

5905.title: Host Device Manufacturer
5905.description: Human readable host device manufacturer name.

5906.title: Host Device Model Number
5906.description: A host device model identifier (manufacturer specified string).

5907.title: Host Device Unique ID
5907.description: The host device unique ID as assigned by an OEM, MNO, or other as the Device ID in the onboarding or manufacturing process.

5908.title: Host Device Software Version
5908.description: Current software version of the host device (manufacturer specified string).

10242.title: 3-Phase Power Meter
10242.description:
This Object provides the information to represent a generic 3-Phase Power Meter.
     LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: 3-Phase Power Meter
items.description:
This Object provides the information to represent a generic 3-Phase Power Meter.
     LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

0.title: Manufacturer
0.description: Human readable manufacturer name

1.title: Model Number
1.description: A model identifier (manufacturer specified string)

2.title: Serial Number
2.description: Serial number of the meter

3.title: Description
3.description: Description of the meter

4.title: Tension R
4.description: Voltage phase 1 (phase to neutral) Units: V.

5.title: Current R
5.description: Current phase 1 Units: A.

6.title: Active Power R
6.description: Active Power phase 1 Units: kW.

7.title: Reactive Power R
7.description: Reactive Power phase 1 Units: kvar.

8.title: Inductive Reactive Power R
8.description: Inductive Reactive Power phase 1 Units: kvar.

9.title: Capacitive Reactive Power R
9.description: Capacitive Reactive Power phase 1 Units: kvar.

10.title: Apparent Power R
10.description: Apparent Power phase 1 Units: kVA.

11.title: Power Factor R
11.description: Power Factor phase 1

12.title: THD-V R
12.description: Total Harmonic Distortion phase 1 (Tension) Units: /100.

13.title: THD-A R
13.description: Total Harmonig Distortion phase 1 (Current) Units: /100.

14.title: Tension S
14.description: Voltage phase 2 (phase to neutral) Units: V.

15.title: Current S
15.description: Current phase 2 Units: A.

16.title: Active Power S
16.description: Active Power phase 2 Units: kW.

17.title: Reactive Power S
17.description: Reactive Power phase 2 Units: kvar.

18.title: Inductive Reactive Power S
18.description: Inductive Reactive Power phase 2 Units: kvar.

19.title: Capacitive Reactive Power S
19.description: Capacitive Reactive Power phase 2 Units: kvar.

24.title: Tension T
24.description: Voltage phase 3 (phase to neutral) Units: V.

28.title: Inductive Reactive Power T
28.description: Inductive Reactive Power phase 3 Units: kvar.

29.title: Capacitive Reactive Power T
29.description: Capacitive Reactive Power phase 3 Units: kvar.

46.title: Tension R-S
46.description: Voltage phase 1 to phase 2 Units: V.

47.title: Tension S-T
47.description: Voltage phase 2 to phase 3 Units: V.

48.title: Tension T-R
48.description: Voltage phase 3 to phase 1 Units: V.

10244.title: VehicleControlUnit
10244.description: This Object provides the information to represent a generic VCU(vehicle control unit). LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: false Mandatory: false

0.title: Vehicle UI State
0.description: The UI state of the vehicle. 0: idle 1: driving 2: charging 3: limp-home 4-15: reserved for future use

1.title: Vehicle Speed
1.description: Current speed of the vehicle. Units: km/h.

2.title: Vehicle Shift Status
2.description: Current shift status of the vehicle. 0: Neutral 1: Forward 2: Reverse

3.title: Vehicle AP Position
3.description: Current position of the accelerator pedal. Units: /100.

4.title: Vehicle Power
4.description: Current power of drive output/regenerative braking. Units: kW.

5.title: Vehicle Drive Energy
5.description: Accumulated drive energy of the vehicle. Units: Wh.

6.title: Vehicle Energy Consumption Efficiency
6.description: Energy consumption efficiency of the vehicle. Units: Wh/km.

7.title: Vehicle Estimated Mileage
7.description: Estimated mileage of current battery capacity. Units: km.

8.title: Vehicle Charge Cable Status
8.description: Whether the charge cable is connected or not. 0: unconnected 1: connected

9.title: Vehicle Charge Status
9.description: Charging status of the vehicle. 1: non-charge mode 2: charging 3: charge completed 4: charging abort abnormally

10.title: Vehicle Charge Voltage
10.description: Charging voltage Units: V.

11.title: Vehicle Charge Current
11.description: Charging current Units: A.

12.title: Vehicle Charge Remaining Time
12.description: Remaining charging time Units: min.

13.title: Battery Pack Voltage
13.description: Voltage of the battery pack Units: V.

14.title: Battery Pack Current
14.description: Current of the battery pack Units: A.

15.title: Battery Pack Remaining Capacity
15.description: Remaining capacity of the battery pack Units: Ah.

16.title: Battery Pack SOC
16.description: SOC(state of charge) of the battery pack Units: /100.

17.title: Battery Pack SOH
17.description: SOH(state of health) of the battery pack Units: /100.

18.title: Battery Cell MinVolt
18.description: Minimum voltage of the battery module (with parallel connection of cells) Units: mV.

19.title: Battery Cell MaxVolt
19.description: Maximum voltage of the battery module (with parallel connection of cells) Units: mV.

20.title: Battery Module MinTemp
20.description: Minimum temperature of the battery module Units: Cel.

21.title: Battery Module MaxTemp
21.description: Maximum temperature of the battery module Units: Cel.

22.title: Battery Connection Status
22.description: Whether the battery is connected or not. 0: unconnected 1: connected

24.title: MCU Voltage
24.description: Voltage of the MCU(motor control unit) Units: V.

25.title: MCU Temperature
25.description: Temperature of MCU(motor control unit) Units: Cel.

26.title: Motor Speed
26.description: Rotational speed of the motor Units: 1/min.

27.title: Motor Temperature
27.description: Temperature of the motor Units: Cel.

28.title: Motor OT Warning
28.description: Whether the motor is OT or not. 0: normal 1: OT warning

29.title: MCU OT Warning
29.description: Whether the MCU is OT or not. 0: normal 1: OT warning

30.title: Battery Pack OT Warning
30.description: Whether the battery pack is OT or not. 0: normal 1: OT warning

31.title: MCU fault
31.description: Status of MCU. 0: normal 1: level 1 minor fault 2: level 2 critical fault

32.title: Motor Error
32.description: Status of the battery pack. 0: normal 1: level D25 minor fault 2: level 2 critical fault

10245.title: Relay Management
10245.description: This LWM2M Object provides a range of eNB related measurements and parameters of which several are changeable. Furthermore, it includes Resources to enable/disable the eNB. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: false Mandatory: false

0.title: eNB Availability
0.description: This field indicates to the CCC whether or not the eNB of the CrowdBox is available for activation: AVAILABLE = TRUE; UNAVAILABLE = FALSE This is set by the CrowdBox itself using an algorithm specific to the use case and based on parameters known to the CrowdBox which may not necessarily be signalled to the network. In the absence of a more specific algorithm, this parameter should be set to AVAILABLE, unless a fault is detected which would prevent activation of the eNB, in which case it should be set to UNAVAILABLE.

1.title: GPS Status
1.description: States whether the CrowdBox GPS receiver is synchronised to GPS time or not: UNSYCHRONISED = FALSE; SYNCHRONISED = TRUE If more than one GPS receiver is used by the CrowdBox, then SYNCHRONISED should be reported only if all receivers are synchronised.

2.title: Orientation
2.description: Orientation of CrowdBox with respect to magnetic north. The reference orientation of the CrowdBox shall be the pointing direction of the eNB antenna(s) or, in the case of an omni-directional CrowdBox antenna, as defined in the accompanying product documentation. Units: deg.

3.title: eNB EARFCN
3.description: EARFCN currently used by the eNB. Highest valid value in 3GPP is currently 46589. If the requested EARFCN is not supported by the eNB, the response should be "Bad Request". The CrowdBox shall only apply a change of this resource upon execution of the "Enable eNB" command.

4.title: eNB Bandwidth
4.description: Bandwidth of the currently used eNB carrier. If the requested bandwidth is not supported by the eNB, the response should be "Bad Request". The CrowdBox shall only apply a change of this resource upon execution of the "Enable eNB" command.

5.title: Backhaul Primary EARFCN
5.description: EARFCN of primary cell used for the backhaul. If the requested EARFCN is not supported by the CrowdBox UE, the response should be "Bad Request". The CrowdBox shall only apply a change of this resource upon execution of the "Enable eNB" command.

6.title: Backhaul Secondary EARFCN
6.description: EARFCN of any secondary cells used for the backhaul, in the event that carrier aggregation is being used. If the requested EARFCN is not supported by the CrowdBox UE, the response should be "Bad Request". The CrowdBox shall only apply a change of this resource upon execution of the "Enable eNB" command.

7.title: Cumulative Measurement Window
7.description: The current measurement interval over which cumulative statistics are collected for the following resources: Cumulative Number of Unique Users, Cumulative Downlink Throughput per Connected User, Cumulative Uplink Throughput per Connected User. Note that this measurement period is a sliding window rather than a granularity period. Measurements should never be reset, but rather old measurements should be removed from the cumulative total as they fall outside of the window. A value of 0 shall be interpreted as meaning only the current value should be reported. A value of 65535 shall be interpreted as an infinite window size (i.e. old measurements are never discarded). Units: s.

8.title: eNB ECI
8.description: A 28 bit E-UTRAN Cell Identifier (ECI) (range 0..2^28-1)

9.title: eNB Status
9.description: This resource indicates the current status of the eNB and can be used by the CCC to change the state from enabled to disabled. TRUE = eNB enabled FALSE = eNB disabled

11.title: eNB Maximum Power
11.description: Maximum power for the eNB measured as the sum of input powers to all antenna connectors. The maximum power per antenna port is equal to the maximum eNB power divided by the number of antenna ports. If the requested power is above or below the maximum or minimum power levels of the eNB, then the power level should be set to the maximum or minimum respectively. The CrowdBox shall only apply a change of this resource upon execution of the "Enable eNB" command. Units: dBm.

12.title: Backhaul Primary q-OffsetFreq
12.description: q-OffsetFreq parameter for the backhaul primary EARFCN in SIB5 of the CrowdBox eNB BCCH. See TS 36.331 for details. Range: dB-24; dB-22 .. dB24 The CrowdBox shall only apply a change of this resource upon execution of the "Enable eNB" command. Units: dB.

13.title: Backhaul Secondary q-OffsetFreq
13.description: q-OffsetFreq parameter for the backhaul secondary EARFCN in SIB5 of the CrowdBox eNB BCCH. See TS 36.331 for details Range: dB-24; dB-22 .. dB24 The CrowdBox shall only apply a change of this resource upon execution of the "Enable eNB" command. Units: dB.

14.title: Neighbour CrowdBox EARFCN
14.description: EARFCN of a neighbour CrowdBox. Each instance of this resource relates to the same instance of resource ID 15.

15.title: Neighbour CrowdBox q-OffsetFreq
15.description: q-OffsetFreq parameter of the Neighbour CrowdBox EARFCN in SIB5 of the Neighbour CrowdBox eNB BCCH. See TS 36.331 for details Range: dB-24; dB-22 .. dB24 Each instance of this resource relates to the same instance of resource ID 14. The CrowdBox shall only apply a change of this resource upon execution of the "Enable eNB" command. Units: dB.

16.title: Serving Macro eNB cellIndividualOffset
16.description: Specifies the value of the cellIndividualOffset parameter applicable to the CrowdBox macro serving cell that is to be signalled to connected UEs in their measurement configuration information . See TS 36.331 for details. The CrowdBox shall only apply a change of this resource upon execution of the "Enable eNB" command. Units: dB.

10246.title: CrowdBox Measurements
10246.description: This LWM2M Object provides CrowdBox-related measurements such as serving cell parameters, backhaul timing advance, and neighbour cell reports. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: false Mandatory: false

0.title: Serving Cell ID
0.description: Serving cell ID as specified by the cellIdentity field broadcast in SIB1 of the serving cell (see TS 36.331).

1.title: Serving Cell RSRP
1.description: Serving cell RSRP, as defined in TS 36.133, Section 9.1.4. Range: RSRP_00; RSRP_01 .. RSRP_97

2.title: Serving Cell RSRQ
2.description: Serving cell RSRQ, as defined in TS 36.133, Section 9.1.7. Range: RSRQ_-30; RSRQ_-29 .. RSRQ_46

3.title: Serving Cell SINR
3.description: SINR of serving cell as estimated by the CrowdBox. Note that this is a proprietary measurement dependent on the UE chipset manufacturer. The UE chipset used should be stated in the accompanying product documentation. Units: dB.

4.title: Cumulative Backhaul Timing Advance
4.description: The cumulative timing advance signalled by the current serving cell to the CrowdBox. This is the sum of the initial timing advance signalled in the MAC payload of the Random Access Response (11 bits, 0 .. 1282) and subsequent adjustments signalled in the MAC PDU of DL-SCH transmissions (6 bits, -31 .. 32). See TS 36.321 for details.

5.title: Neighbour Cell Report
5.description: A link to the "Neighbour Cell Report" object for each neighbour cell of the CrowdBox.

10247.title: Neighbour Cell Report
10247.description: This LWM2M Object provides the neighbour cell report. The CrowdBox Measurements Object and the Connected UE Report Object have both Objlnk Resources pointing to this Object. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: Neighbour Cell Report
items.description: This LWM2M Object provides the neighbour cell report. The CrowdBox Measurements Object and the Connected UE Report Object have both Objlnk Resources pointing to this Object. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

0.title: Neighbour PCI
0.description: Physical Cell ID of neighbouring LTE cell, as defined in TS 36.211

1.title: Neighbour Cell ID
1.description: Neighbour cell ID as specified by the cellIdentity field broadcast in SIB1 of the neighbour cell (see TS 36.331).

2.title: Neighbour Cell Rank
2.description: Current neighbour cell rank. Neighbour cells should be ordered (ranked) by the CrowdBox according to neighbour cell RSRP, with a higher RSRP corresponding to a lower index. Hence the neighbouring cell with the highest RSRP should be neighbour cell 0, the second neighbour cell 1, and so on.

3.title: Neighbour Cell RSRP
3.description: Neighbour cell RSRP, as defined in TS 36.133, Section 9.1.4. Range: RSRP_00; RSRP_01 .. RSRP_97

4.title: Neighbour Cell RSRQ
4.description: Neighbour cell RSRQ, as defined in TS 36.133, Section 9.1.7. Range: RSRQ_-30; RSRQ_-29 .. RSRQ_46

10248.title: Connected UE Measurements
10248.description: This LWM2M Object provides a range of measurements of connected UEs and provides an Object link to the Connected UE report. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: false Mandatory: false

0.title: Number of Connected Users
0.description: The number of different UEs currently connected to the eNB (i.e. in RRC_CONNECTED state).

1.title: Cumulative Number of Unique Users
1.description: The number of different UEs that have connected to the eNB over the immediately preceding period specified by the "Cumulative Measurement Window" field.

2.title: Connected UE Report
2.description: Provides an Object link to the Connected UE Report which provides a range of information related to the connected UEs.

10249.title: Connected UE Report
10249.description: This LWM2M Object provides a range of information related to the connected UEs. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: Connected UE Report
items.description: This LWM2M Object provides a range of information related to the connected UEs. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

0.title: Connected User MMEC
0.description: MMEC signalled by the UE to the eNB in the RRCConnectionRequest message (see TS 36.331).

1.title: Connected User M-TMSI
1.description: M-TMSI signalled by the UE to the eNB in the RRCConnectionRequest message (see TS 36.331).

2.title: Serving Cell (CrowdBox) eNB RSRP
2.description: The RSRP of the CrowdBox eNB, as defined in TS 36.133, Section 9.1.4. Range: RSRP_00; RSRP_01 .. RSRP_97

3.title: Serving Cell (CrowdBox) eNB RSRQ
3.description: The RSRQ of the CrowdBox eNB, as defined in TS 36.133, Section 9.1.7. Range: RSRQ_-30; RSRQ_-29 .. RSRQ_46

4.title: Cumulative Timing Advance per Connected User
4.description: The cumulative timing advance signalled by the eNB to each currently connected UE. This is the sum of the initial timing advance signalled in the MAC payload of the Random Access Response (11 bits, 0 .. 1282) and subsequent adjustments signalled in the MAC PDU of DL-SCH transmissions (6 bits, -31 .. 32). See TS 36.321 for details.

5.title: Last downlink CQI report per Connected User
5.description: The last downlink wideband CQI reported by a connected user the eNB. The CQI format is defined in Table 7.2.3-1 of TS 36.213.

6.title: Cumulative Downlink Throughput per Connected User
6.description: The total number of MAC bytes sent to the connected user over the immediately preceding period specified by the "Cumulative Measurement Window" field. A 32 bit value with range 0..2^32-1. Units: B.

7.title: Cumulative Uplink Throughput per Connected User
7.description: The total number of MAC bytes received from the connected user over the immediately preceding period specified by the "Cumulative Measurement Window" field. A 32 bit value with range 0..2^32-1. Units: B.

8.title: Neighbour Cell Report
8.description: A link to the "Neighbour Cell Report" object for each neighbour cell reported to the CrowdBox by the connected UE

10250.title: App Data Container
10250.description: This LWM2M Object is used for reporting application data of a device. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: false Mandatory: false

0.title: UL data
0.description:
Uplink application data, e.g. gas meter reporting data. Units: 
        .

1.title: DL data
1.description:
Downlink application data, e.g. application response message of uplink data. Units: 
        .

10251.title: AT Command
10251.description: Used to execute an AT command on a cellular modem LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: AT Command
items.description: Used to execute an AT command on a cellular modem LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

0.title: Command
0.description: The AT command to run. Example: AT+CREG? to query registration status

1.title: Response
1.description: Response to the AT command. Example: +CREG:0,5 If multiple lines are returned as the modem response, each line will be returned in a separate resource.

2.title: Status
2.description: Status of the command execution as returned by the modem. Typical values:OK ERROR

3.title: Timeout
3.description: Amount of time in seconds allowed for the modem to respond to the command.

10252.title: Manifest
10252.description: This object provides a range of information related to updating packages on a device LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: false Mandatory: false

1.title: Manifest
1.description:
Content of a new manifest Units: 
        .

2.title: State
2.description:
Current state of manifest processing
0.	Uninitialised
1.	Idle
2.	Processing manifest
3.	Awaiting download approval
4.	Downloading 
5.	Downloaded
6.	Awaiting application approval
7.	Updating
8.	Rebooting Units: 
        .

3.title: Manifest Result
3.description:
Final result of the device processing a manifest.
0.	Uninitialised
1.	Success
2.	Manifest timeout. The Manifest URI has timed-out.
3.	Manifest not found. The Manifest URI not found.
4.	Manifest failed integrity check. The manifest integrity check failed. 
5.	Manifest rejected. The Manifest attributes do not apply to this device.
6.	Manifest certificate not found
7.	Manifest signature failed. The Manifest signature is not recognised by this device.
8.	Dependent manifest not found
9.	Not enough storage for the new asset
10.	Out of memory during download process
11.	Connection lost during download process
12.	Asset failed integrity check
13.	Unsupported asset type
14.	Invalid asset URI
15.	Timed out downloading asset
16.	Unsupported delta format
17.	Unsupported encryption format
18.	Asset update successfully completed
19.	Asset updated successfully after recovery Units: 
        .

4.title: Payload Result
4.description:
Contains payload-specific errors or output. Units: 
        .

5.title: Asset Hash
5.description:
Hash of the installed asset. Units: 
        .

6.title: Manifest version
6.description:
Version of the current manifest. Units: 
        .

7.title: Asset Installation Progress
7.description:
Progress update of the asset installation process (in bytes). Units: 
        .

8.title: Campaign Id
8.description:
Id of campaign affecting this device. There currently isnâ€™t any logic on the server or the client to handle this. Units: 
        .

10259.title: System Log
10259.description: This object provides read access to log buffers as well as limited configuration of logging services. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: System Log
items.description: This object provides read access to log buffers as well as limited configuration of logging services. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

0.title: Name
0.description:
Short name describing the log source represented by this particular instance.
For syslog-compatible log sources this value should be "syslog". If multiple syslog-compatible log sources exist on a device then each should be given a distinct name that is then prefixed with "syslog-". Units: 
        .

1.title: Read All
1.description:
Read the entire current contents of the log buffer.
Result is delivered as a display-formatted UTF-8 string, with each message entry on a new line. Units: 
        .

2.title: Read
2.description:
Similar to Read All, but only reads log entries that have arrived since the last time this log buffer was read.
If the LwM2M client is connected to multiple servers then the last read position should be tracked separately for each server.
If this is the first attempt to read the log for a given connection then this resource behaves the same as Read All. Units: 
        .

3.title: Enabled
3.description:
Enable or disable log capture for this source.
If this resource is not provided by an implementation, then the existence of a System Log instance is taken as implicit confirmation that the log source it represents is currently enabled. Units: 
        .

4.title: Capture Level
4.description:
For log sources that support message priorities, this resource configures the minimum priority to capture.
For syslog-compatible log sources the following enumeration must be used: 1 = Emergency, 2 = Alert, 3 = Critical, 4 = Error, 5 = Warning, 6 = Notice, 7 = Info, 8 = Debug.
For other log sources this is left up to the implementer, with the requirement that consecutive values are used, starting at 1 and sorted so that message verbosity increases as the number ascends. Units: 
        .

10262.title: Interval Data Delivery
10262.description: The Interval Data Delivery object provides an optimised means for managing the delivery of interval data from multiple Interval Data Object instances.  LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: Interval Data Delivery
items.description: The Interval Data Delivery object provides an optimised means for managing the delivery of interval data from multiple Interval Data Object instances.  LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

0.title: Name
0.description: The Name resource provides a way to identify different Interval Data Delivery instances. Name is a readable and writable attribute. Name is defined as an arbitrary length text string

1.title: Interval Data Links
1.description: The Interval Data Links resource is a set of object links that point to each of the Interval Data Object Instances that are managed by this Interval Data Delivery Object Instance. An Object Link is two 16-bit integer values representing the Object ID and the Object Instance ID. This resource can have multiple instances allowing this Interval Data Delivery object to manage many Interval Data instances.

2.title: Latest Payload
2.description: The Latest Payload resource is a multiple instance resource representing the Latest Payload resource from each of the Interval Data objects defined in the Interval Data Links Resource. When this payload is delivered to the LwM2M server, via either a read request or a confirmed observation on this Object, Object Instance or Resource, the Latest Delivered Interval should for each of the Interval Data objects defined in the Interval Data Links Resource must be updated. When no new data exists for a specific Interval Data instance and empty Opaque value should be provided. When a specific Interval Data Instance is disabled (Recording Enabled Resource = 0), no payload data should be provided at all.

3.title: Schedule
3.description: The Schedule resource provides link to a schedule object. This Schedule object is used to provide fine grain control the Notification schedule delivery when the default LwM2M NOTIFICATION attributes do not provide sufficient control. If no schedule is required, an Object Link referencing no Object Instance will contain the concatenation of 2 MAX-ID values (null link).

10263.title: Event Data Delivery
10263.description: The Event Data Delivery object provides a simple means for managing the delivery of event data from multiple Event Data Object instances.  LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: Event Data Delivery
items.description: The Event Data Delivery object provides a simple means for managing the delivery of event data from multiple Event Data Object instances.  LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

0.title: Name
0.description: The Name resource provides a way to identify different Event Data Delivery instances. Name is a readable and writable attribute. Name is defined as an arbitrary length text string

1.title: Event Data Links
1.description: The Event Data Links resource is a set of object links that point to each of the Event Data Object Instances that are managed by this Event Data Delivery Object Instance. An Object Link is two 16-bit integer values representing the Object ID and the Object Instance ID. This resource can have multiple instances allowing this Event Data Delivery object to manage many Event Data instances.

2.title: Latest Eventlog
2.description:
The Latest Eventlog resource is a multiple instance resource representing the Latest Eventlog resource from each of the Event Data objects defined in the Event Data Links Resource. When this payload is delivered to the LwM2M server, via either a read request or a confirmed observation on this Object, Object Instance or Resource, the Latest Delivered Event Time for each of the Event Data objects defined in the Event Data Links Resource must be updated. When no new event data exists for any of the linked Event Data instances an empty Opaque value should be provided.

If this resource has an LwM2M server observation and one of the Event Data Instance is configured as Realtime and has been triggered, the Event Data Delivery object must send all undelivered events for all linked Event Data objects.

3.title: Schedule
3.description: The Schedule resource provides link to a schedule object. This Schedule object is used to provide fine grain control the Notification schedule delivery when the default LwM2M NOTIFICATION attributes do not provide sufficient control. If no schedule is required, an Object Link referencing no Object Instance will contain the concatenation of 2 MAX-ID values (null link).

10264.title: Delivery Schedule
10264.description: The Delivery Schedule object provides a means for controlling the periodic delivery of interval and event data to the LwM2M server. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: Delivery Schedule
items.description: The Delivery Schedule object provides a means for controlling the periodic delivery of interval and event data to the LwM2M server. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

0.title: Schedule Start Time
0.description: Schedule Start Time is a readable and writable resource representing the number of seconds past midnight for which this schedule commences

1.title: Schedule UTC Offset
1.description: The Schedule UTC Offset resource is a readable and writable resource representing the time zone offset for the Schedule Start Time Resource for this Delivery Schedule instance. If this resource is empty, the application should use the UTC offset provided in the Device [/3/0/14] object instance resource or UTC if not provided.  UTC+X [ISO 8601].

2.title: Delivery Frequency
2.description:
The Delivery Frequency resource is a readable and writable resource representing the number of seconds between deliveries. It is recommended that the Delivery Frequency be set to a devisor of 24 hours (86400 seconds) to provide a consistent interval period. Examples of Delivery Frequency include:-
30 = Every 30 seconds
600 = Every 10 minutes
1800 = Every 30 minutes
3600 = Hourly
7200 = Every 2 hours
14400 = Every 4 hours
43200 = Every 12 hours
86400 = Every Day
172600 = Every Second Day

3.title: Randomised Delivery Window
3.description: The Randomised Delivery Window resource is a readable and writable resource representing a randomisation widow in seconds for the triggering of the notification delivery to the LwM2M server. If not provided, the randomised delivery window should default to 0 and the Notification should be sent immediately. The Randomised Delivery Window resource should be set to a value smaller than the delivery frequency.

4.title: Number of Retries
4.description: The Number of Retries resource is a readable and writable resource representing the number of retry attempts that should be attempted when the delivery notification is not successful. If not provided, this value defaults to 0 and no retries are attempted. This retry behaviour is at an application level and should be set with consideration of standard CoAP retry behaviour.

5.title: Retry Period
5.description: The Retry Period resource is a readable and writable resource representing the number of seconds between each application level retry.

10265.title: Leakage Detection Configuration
10265.description: The leakage detection configuration object provides a means for configuring the timing and sampling frequency of a vibration based network leak detector LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: false Mandatory: false

0.title: Sample Times
0.description: Sample Times is a readable and writable multi value resource used to control when leak detection vibration sampling should occur. This is an integer value representing seconds since midnight

1.title: Sample UTC Offset
1.description: The Sample UTC Offset resource is a readable and writable resource representing the time zone offset for this Leakage Detection Schedule instance. If this resource is empty, the application should use the UTC offset provided in the Device [/3/0/14] object instance resource or UTC if not provided.

2.title: Detection Mode
2.description:
Detection Mode is a readable and writeable resource used to indicate which mode to run the leak detection sensor. Values are one of:-
0. Disabled
1. Alarm Only (default)
2. Top Frequency Values
3. All Frequency Values

Disabled (0)  the leak detection function should be disabled.
Alarm Only (1)  for this mode no detailed frequency data is provided to the LwM2M server and an alarm is raised if the Leakage Detection Daughter board indicates that leak was detected. 
Top Frequency Values (2)  for this mode, only the top (Top Frequency Count) values will be delivered to the LwM2M server via the Frequency Value Resource
All Frequency Values(3)  for this mode, all frequency values for all frequency bands will be provided to the LwM2M server via the Frequency Value Resource

3.title: Top Frequency Count
3.description: Top Frequency Count is a readable and writeable resource used represent the number of samples to provide if the Detection Mode is set to Mode 2 (Top Frequency Values). If not provided, this value should default to 3

4.title: Frequency Thresholds
4.description:
Frequency Thresholds is a multiple value readable and writeable resource used to represent upper bound thresholds for each of the frequency bands configured on the daughter board. Being a multiple value resource, this resource only needs to contain the values that are required to override the default values provided by the daughter board firmware.  As an example if the frequency threshold for band 7 and band 52 needs to be overridden, then this resource should just contain those two values:-
/TBD/0/4/7 = 123
/TBD/0/4/52 = 345

5.title: Frequency Values
5.description:
Frequency Values is a multiple value readonly resource used represent the latest frequency values recorded by the daughter board. In Detection Mode 2 (Top Frequency Values) only the number of values configured in Top Frequency Count will be provided. As an example, if the Top Frequency Count is 3 and the top three frequency threshold deviations were on band 8, 44 and 101, this resource would present:-
/TBD/0/5/8 = 434
/TBD/0/5/44 = 39
/TBD/0/5/101 = 349
In Detection Mode 3, this resource would present all frequency readings from 1 through to the number of bands measured by the board.
This resource can either be observed by the LwM2M server (and subsequently notified by the Client daily) or Read adhoc from the LwM2M server.

7.title: Firmware Version
7.description: Firmware Version is a readonly resource representing the current firmware version of the Daughter Board.

10266.title: Water Flow Readings
10266.description: Measures the flow of water in regular intervals LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: Water Flow Readings
items.description: Measures the flow of water in regular intervals LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

6000.title: Interval Period
6000.description:
The Interval Period resource is an Integer value representing the width in seconds of the intervals being managed by this interval data object. This resource is read only and can only be changed by resource 11 (Change Interval Configuration). It is recommended that the Interval Period be set to a devisor of 24 hours (86400 seconds) to provide a consistent interval period. Examples of Interval Period include:-
30 = Every 30 seconds
600 = Every 10 minutes
1800 = Every 30 minutes
3600 = Hourly
7200 = Every 2 hours
14400 = Every 4 hours
43200 = Every 12 hours
86400 = Every Day
172600 = Every Second Day Units: s.

6001.title: Interval Start Offset
6001.description: The Interval Start Offset resource is a read only resource representing the number of seconds past midnight for which the first interval is recorded. If this resource is empty, it is assumed that the intervals are midnight aligned. This can be used to adjust interval boundaries. As an example, an Interval Period of 3600 seconds and an Interval Start time of 300 represents hourly interval data, starting at 00:05. Units: s.

6002.title: Interval UTC Offset
6002.description: The Interval UTC Offset resource is a read only resource representing the time zone offset for this Interval Data instance. If this resource is empty, the application should use the UTC offset provided in the Device [/3/0/14] object instance resource or UTC if not provided. UTC+X [ISO 8601].

6003.title: Interval Collection Start Time
6003.description: The Collection Start Time resource is a read only resource representing the time when the first interval was recorded on the device. Interval times represent the end of the interval, not the beginning. As an example, the first four hourly interval past midnight will have a timestamp of 04:00 (adjusting for UTC offset). Unix Time. A signed integer representing the number of seconds since Jan 1 st, 1970 in the UTC time zone.

6004.title: Oldest Recorded Interval
6004.description: The Oldest Recorded Interval resource is a read-only resource representing the oldest available interval on the device. Interval times represent the end of the interval, not the beginning. Unix Time. A signed integer representing the number of seconds since Jan 1 st, 1970 in the UTC time zone.

6005.title: Last Delivered Interval
6005.description: The Last Delivered Interval is a readable and writable resource used to represent the last interval delivered to the LwM2M server. Interval times represent the end of the interval, not the beginning. The setting of this resource is implementation specific but should be updated based on, either a Read request of the Latest Payload from the LwM2M server or via a confirmed delivery of Notify operation of the Latest Payload resource. This resource is writable to allow the server to adjust the Last Delivered Interval value if the server and client is out of sync. Unix Time. A signed integer representing the number of seconds since Jan 1 st, 1970 in the UTC time zone.

6006.title: Latest Recorded Interval
6006.description: The Latest Recorded Interval is a readable resource representing the currently highest recorded interval on the device. Interval times represent the end of the interval, not the beginning. Unix Time. A signed integer representing the number of seconds since Jan 1 st, 1970 in the UTC time zone.

6007.title: Interval Delivery Midnight Aligned
6007.description: The Delivery Midnight Aligned is a readable and writable resource used to indicate if data is delivered only to the previous midnight (1) or if part-day data can be delivered (0). Calculating Midnight should consider the Interval UTC Offset resource, or if empty, the Device [/3/0/14] object instance resource.

6009.title: Interval Historical Read Payload
6009.description: The Historical Read Payload resource is the representation of the data requested by the Historical Interval Read executable resource. The format of this Opaque value should be identical to the Latest Payload resource. If no Historical Interval Read has been executed, this resource should return and empty Opaque value. This resource can either be Read from the Server or set up as an observation and Notified to the server as soon as the historical data is available. When this payload is delivered to the LwM2M server, via either a read request or a confirmed observation on this Object, Object Instance or Resource, the Historical Read Payload should be set to an empty Opaque value.

6028.title: Status
6028.description: Recording Enabled is a read-only resource providing an indication of if interval data is currently being recorded for this object instance. Refer to re-usable resource LogStatus for further details.

6029.title: Latest Payload
6029.description:
The Latest Payload resource is a read-only serialised Opaque (Binary) representation of all the Interval Data between the Last Delivered Interval and the Latest Recorded Interval, accounting for the Delivery Midnight Aligned resource. When this payload is delivered to the LwM2M server, via either a read request or a confirmed observation on this Object, Object Instance or Resource, the Latest Delivered Interval should be updated. When no new data exists, an empty Opaque value should be provided.

The payload data can be provided in an implementation specific serialisation, but by default for fixed length values should use the OMA-LwM2M CBOR format encoded as follows:

1. 8-bit integer, value 2 representing OMA-LwM2M CBOR format.
2. Interval Data Instance ID/ Class [16-bit integer]
3. Timestamp of first Interval [32-bit integer] representing the number of seconds since Jan 1st, 1970 in the UTC time zone.
4. Interval Period in seconds [32-bit integer]
5. Number of intervals in Payload [16-bit integer]
6. Number of Values Per Interval [8-bit integer]
7. Size of Value 1 in bits [8-bit integer]
8. Size of Value 2 in bits [8-bit integer]
...
9. Size of Value N in bits [8-bit integer]
10. Interval 1 Value 1 [x bits]
11. Interval 1 Value 2 [x bits]
...
12. Interval 1 Value N [x bits]
...
13. Interval N Value N [x bits]

If for some implementation specific reason, there are missing intervals in the sequence, the payload may consist of multiple blocks of the above serialised data (appended into a single binary opaque value), each block representing a continuous series of interval data.

10267.title: Daily Maximum Flow Rate Readings
10267.description: Measures the maximum flow rate and its time stamp for specified period LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: Daily Maximum Flow Rate Readings
items.description: Measures the maximum flow rate and its time stamp for specified period LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

6009.title: Interval Historical Read Payload
6009.description: The Historical Read Payload resource is the representation of the data requested by the Historical Interval Read executable resource. The format of this Opaque value should be identical to the Latest Payload resource. If no Historical Interval Read has been executed, this resource should return and empty Opaque value. This resource can either be Read from the Server or set up as an observation and Notified to the server as soon as the historical data is available. When this payload is delivered to the LwM2M server, via either a read request or a confirmed observation on this Object, Object Instance or Resource, the Historical Read Payload should be set to an empty Opaque value.

6028.title: Status
6028.description: Recording Enabled is a read-only resource providing an indication of if interval data is currently being recorded for this object instance. Refer to re-usable resource LogStatus for further details.

6029.title: Latest Payload
6029.description:
The Latest Payload resource is a read-only serialised Opaque (Binary) representation of all the Interval Data between the Last Delivered Interval and the Latest Recorded Interval, accounting for the Delivery Midnight Aligned resource. When this payload is delivered to the LwM2M server, via either a read request or a confirmed observation on this Object, Object Instance or Resource, the Latest Delivered Interval should be updated. When no new data exists, an empty Opaque value should be provided.

The payload data can be provided in an implementation specific serialisation, but by default for fixed length values should use the OMA-LwM2M CBOR format encoded as follows:

1. 8-bit integer, value 2 representing OMA-LwM2M CBOR format.
2. Interval Data Instance ID/ Class [16-bit integer]
3. Timestamp of first Interval [32-bit integer] representing the number of seconds since Jan 1st, 1970 in the UTC time zone.
4. Interval Period in seconds [32-bit integer]
5. Number of intervals in Payload [16-bit integer]
6. Number of Values Per Interval [8-bit integer]
7. Size of Value 1 in bits [8-bit integer]
8. Size of Value 2 in bits [8-bit integer]
...
9. Size of Value N in bits [8-bit integer]
10. Interval 1 Value 1 [x bits]
11. Interval 1 Value 2 [x bits]
...
12. Interval 1 Value N [x bits]
...
13. Interval N Value N [x bits]

If for some implementation specific reason, there are missing intervals in the sequence, the payload may consist of multiple blocks of the above serialised data (appended into a single binary opaque value), each block representing a continuous series of interval data.

10268.title: Temperature Readings
10268.description: Periodic temperature measurements LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: Temperature Readings
items.description: Periodic temperature measurements LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

6000.title: Interval Period
6000.description:
The Interval Period resource is an Integer value representing the width in seconds of the intervals being managed by this interval data object. This resource is read only and can only be changed by resource 11 (Change Interval Configuration). It is recommended that the Interval Period be set to a devisor of 24 hours (86400 seconds) to provide a consistent interval period. Examples of Interval Period include:-
30 = Every 30 seconds
600 = Every 10 minutes
1800 = Every 30 minutes
3600 = Hourly
7200 = Every 2 hours
14400 = Every 4 hours
43200 = Every 12 hours
86400 = Every Day
172600 = Every Second Day Units: s.

6001.title: Interval Start Offset
6001.description: The Interval Start Offset resource is a read only resource representing the number of seconds past midnight for which the first interval is recorded. If this resource is empty, it is assumed that the intervals are midnight aligned. This can be used to adjust interval boundaries. As an example, an Interval Period of 3600 seconds and an Interval Start time of 300 represents hourly interval data, starting at 00:05. Units: s.

6002.title: Interval UTC Offset
6002.description: The Interval UTC Offset resource is a read only resource representing the time zone offset for this Interval Data instance. If this resource is empty, the application should use the UTC offset provided in the Device [/3/0/14] object instance resource or UTC if not provided. UTC+X [ISO 8601].

6003.title: Interval Collection Start Time
6003.description: The Collection Start Time resource is a read only resource representing the time when the first interval was recorded on the device. Interval times represent the end of the interval, not the beginning. As an example, the first four hourly interval past midnight will have a timestamp of 04:00 (adjusting for UTC offset). Unix Time. A signed integer representing the number of seconds since Jan 1 st, 1970 in the UTC time zone.

6004.title: Oldest Recorded Interval
6004.description: The Oldest Recorded Interval resource is a read-only resource representing the oldest available interval on the device. Interval times represent the end of the interval, not the beginning. Unix Time. A signed integer representing the number of seconds since Jan 1 st, 1970 in the UTC time zone.

6005.title: Last Delivered Interval
6005.description: The Last Delivered Interval is a readable and writable resource used to represent the last interval delivered to the LwM2M server. Interval times represent the end of the interval, not the beginning. The setting of this resource is implementation specific but should be updated based on, either a Read request of the Latest Payload from the LwM2M server or via a confirmed delivery of Notify operation of the Latest Payload resource. This resource is writable to allow the server to adjust the Last Delivered Interval value if the server and client is out of sync. Unix Time. A signed integer representing the number of seconds since Jan 1 st, 1970 in the UTC time zone.

6006.title: Latest Recorded Interval
6006.description: The Latest Recorded Interval is a readable resource representing the currently highest recorded interval on the device. Interval times represent the end of the interval, not the beginning. Unix Time. A signed integer representing the number of seconds since Jan 1 st, 1970 in the UTC time zone.

6007.title: Interval Delivery Midnight Aligned
6007.description: The Delivery Midnight Aligned is a readable and writable resource used to indicate if data is delivered only to the previous midnight (1) or if part-day data can be delivered (0). Calculating Midnight should consider the Interval UTC Offset resource, or if empty, the Device [/3/0/14] object instance resource.

6009.title: Interval Historical Read Payload
6009.description: The Historical Read Payload resource is the representation of the data requested by the Historical Interval Read executable resource. The format of this Opaque value should be identical to the Latest Payload resource. If no Historical Interval Read has been executed, this resource should return and empty Opaque value. This resource can either be Read from the Server or set up as an observation and Notified to the server as soon as the historical data is available. When this payload is delivered to the LwM2M server, via either a read request or a confirmed observation on this Object, Object Instance or Resource, the Historical Read Payload should be set to an empty Opaque value.

6028.description: Recording Enabled is a read-only resource providing an indication of if interval data is currently being recorded for this object instance. Refer to re-usable resource LogStatus for further details.

7. Size of Value 1 in bits [8-bit integer]
8. Size of Value 2 in bits [8-bit integer]
...
9. Size of Value N in bits [8-bit integer]
10. Interval 1 Value 1 [x bits]

10272.title: Water Meter Customer Leakage Alarm
10272.description: A binary flag indicating continual usage (e.g. greater than 5 L/h for 24 hours and the flow never returning to zero at any time). LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: Water Meter Customer Leakage Alarm
items.description: A binary flag indicating continual usage (e.g. greater than 5 L/h for 24 hours and the flow never returning to zero at any time). LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

6011.title: Event Type
6011.description:
Event Type is a readable and writable resource used to represent how this event will behave. Event Type should be one of the following values:-
0. Disabled
1. Alarm Current State
2. Alarm State Change Log
3. Event Log

When the Event Type is set to Disabled (0), this event will not be recorded by the device. No Latest Eventlog payload should be delivered for events that are Disabled.
When the Event Type is set to Alarm Current State (1), this Event is treated as an alarm state manager and the Latest Eventlog Payload will only contain the current state of this alarm.
When the Event Type is set to Alarm State Change Log (2), the Event is treated as an alarm that reports whenever the Alarm is either set or cleared. The Latest Eventlog Payload will contain all alarm transitions since the previous delivery in this mode.
When the Event Type is set to Event Log (3), this object instance is treated as a raw event log. It is used to manage and deliver events. The Latest Eventlog Payload will contain all events since the previous delivery in this mode.

See the Event Log Payload for examples of each of these modes.

6012.title: Alarm Realtime
6012.description: Realtime is a readable and writable resource used to indicate if an event should report immediately (1) at the point of occurrence, or delivered periodically as part of the Latest Eventlog Payload.

6013.title: Alarm State
6013.description: Alarm State is a read-only resource used to indicate the current alarm state for this Event configuration. This is only applicable if the Event Type is Alarm Current State (1) or Alarm State Change (2).

6014.title: Alarm Set Threshold
6014.description: Set Threshold is a readable and writable resource used to represent the threshold for when an alarm is triggered. This resource is used in conjunction with the Set Operator resource.

6015.title: Alarm Set Operator
6015.description:
Set Operator is a readable and writable resource used in conjunction with the Set Threshold to represent when an alarm is triggered. This resource should be set to one of the following values:-
0. Greater Than or Equal to
1. Less Than or Equal to 
By setting the Set Operator to Greater Than (0), when the measured value for this event exceeds the Set Threshold resource, the event is considered to be in an Alarm State of 1
By setting the Set Operator to Less Than (1), when the measured value for this event falls below the Set Threshold resource, the event is considered to be in an Alarm State of 1

6016.title: Alarm Clear Threshold

Event Type = Alarm Current State (1)

6011.title: Event Type
6011.description:
Event Type is a readable and writable resource used to represent how this event will behave. Event Type should be one of the following values:-
0. Disabled
1. Alarm Current State
2. Alarm State Change Log
3. Event Log

When the Event Type is set to Disabled (0), this event will not be recorded by the device. No Latest Eventlog payload should be delivered for events that are Disabled.
When the Event Type is set to Alarm Current State (1), this Event is treated as an alarm state manager and the Latest Eventlog Payload will only contain the current state of this alarm.
When the Event Type is set to Alarm State Change Log (2), the Event is treated as an alarm that reports whenever the Alarm is either set or cleared. The Latest Eventlog Payload will contain all alarm transitions since the previous delivery in this mode.
When the Event Type is set to Event Log (3), this object instance is treated as a raw event log. It is used to manage and deliver events. The Latest Eventlog Payload will contain all events since the previous delivery in this mode.

See the Event Log Payload for examples of each of these modes.

The Latest Eventlog Payload resource is a read-only serialised Opaque (Binary) representation of all the Event Data between the Last Delivered Event Time and the Latest Recorded Event Time. When this payload is delivered to the LwM2M server, via either a read request or a confirmed observation on this Object, Object Instance or Resource, the Latest Delivered Interval should be updated. When no new data exists, an empty Opaque value should be provided.

The payload data can be provided in an implementation specific serialisation, but by default for fixed length values should use the OMA-LwM2M CBOR format encoded with one of these schemes:-

Event Type = Alarm Current State (1)

In this mode, only the current alarm state should be reported

1. 8-bit integer, value 2 representing OMA-LwM2M CBOR format.
2. Event Code [16-bit integer]
3. Event Type [8-bit Integer] - Alarm Current State (1)
4. Alarm Timestamp [32-bit unsigned integer] representing the number of seconds since Jan 1st, 1970 in the UTC time zone.
5. Alarm State [8-bit Integer]

10277.title: Water Meter Low Pressure Alarm
10277.description: Where supported by the meter this is an alarm that should be raised if the meter detects pressure below a pre-configured threshold. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

items.title: Water Meter Low Pressure Alarm
items.description: Where supported by the meter this is an alarm that should be raised if the meter detects pressure below a pre-configured threshold. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

6011.title: Event Type
6011.description:
Event Type is a readable and writable resource used to represent how this event will behave. Event Type should be one of the following values:-
0. Disabled
1. Alarm Current State
2. Alarm State Change Log
3. Event Log

When the Event Type is set to Disabled (0), this event will not be recorded by the device. No Latest Eventlog payload should be delivered for events that are Disabled.
When the Event Type is set to Alarm Current State (1), this Event is treated as an alarm state manager and the Latest Eventlog Payload will only contain the current state of this alarm.
When the Event Type is set to Alarm State Change Log (2), the Event is treated as an alarm that reports whenever the Alarm is either set or cleared. The Latest Eventlog Payload will contain all alarm transitions since the previous delivery in this mode.
When the Event Type is set to Event Log (3), this object instance is treated as a raw event log. It is used to manage and deliver events. The Latest Eventlog Payload will contain all events since the previous delivery in this mode.

See the Event Log Payload for examples of each of these modes.

6012.title: Alarm Realtime
6012.description: Realtime is a readable and writable resource used to indicate if an event should report immediately (1) at the point of occurrence, or delivered periodically as part of the Latest Eventlog Payload.

6013.title: Alarm State
6013.description: Alarm State is a read-only resource used to indicate the current alarm state for this Event configuration. This is only applicable if the Event Type is Alarm Current State (1) or Alarm State Change (2).

6014.title: Alarm Set Threshold
6014.description: Set Threshold is a readable and writable resource used to represent the threshold for when an alarm is triggered. This resource is used in conjunction with the Set Operator resource.

6015.title: Alarm Set Operator
6015.description:
Set Operator is a readable and writable resource used in conjunction with the Set Threshold to represent when an alarm is triggered. This resource should be set to one of the following values:-
0. Greater Than or Equal to
1. Less Than or Equal to 
By setting the Set Operator to Greater Than (0), when the measured value for this event exceeds the Set Threshold resource, the event is considered to be in an Alarm State of 1
By setting the Set Operator to Less Than (1), when the measured value for this event falls below the Set Threshold resource, the event is considered to be in an Alarm State of 1

6016.title: Alarm Clear Threshold
6016.description: Clear Threshold is a readable and writable resource used to represent the threshold for when an alarm is cleared. This resource is used in conjunction with the Clear Operator resource.

6017.title: Alarm Clear Operator
6017.description:
Clear Operator is a readable and writable resource used in conjunction with the Clear Threshold to represent when an alarm is Cleared. This resource should be set to one of the following values:-
0. Greater Than or Equal to
1. Less Than or Equal to
By setting the Clear Operator to Greater Than (0), when the measured value for this event exceeds the Clear Threshold resource, the event is considered to be in an Alarm State of 0
By setting the Clear Operator to Less Than (1), when the measured value for this event falls below the Clear Threshold resource, the event is considered to be in an Alarm State of 0

6018.title: Alarm Maximum Event Count
6018.description: Maximum Event Count is a readable and writable resource used provide a ceiling on the number of events that can be raised within the time period defined in Maximum Event Period resource. If no Maximum Event Count is set, the number of events recorded is unconstrained. The intent of this resource is to control the number of events reported, particularly in the case of a faulty sensor.

6019.title: Alarm Maximum Event Period
6019.description: Maximum Event Period is a readable and writable resource used in conjunction with the Maximum Event Count resource to control the number of events that can be raised in a given period. Maximum Event Period is an integer value representing the number of seconds for which the Maximum Event Count is measured. If no Maximum Event Period is set, the number of events recorded is unconstrained. The intent of this resource is to control the number of events reported, particularly in the case of a faulty sensor. Units: s.

6020.title: Latest Delivered Event Time
6020.description: Latest Delivered Event Time is a readable and writable resource to represent the last recorded time that an event was delivered for this event code to the LwM2M server. The setting of this resource is implementation specific but should be updated based on, either a Read request of the Latest Eventlog Payload from the LwM2M server or via a confirmed delivery of Notify operation of the Latest Eventlog Payload resource. This resource is writable to allow the server to adjust the Last Delivered Event Time value if the server and client is out of sync. Unix Time. A signed integer representing the number of seconds since Jan 1 st, 1970 in the UTC time zone.

6021.title: Latest Recorded Event Time
6021.description: Latest Recorded Event Time is a readonly resource used to represent the last recorded event time for this object instance on the device Unix Time. A signed integer representing the number of seconds since Jan 1 st, 1970 in the UTC time zone.

6023.title: Alarm Auto Clear
6023.description: Auto Clear Alarm is a readable and writable resource used to indicate if an alarm is automatically cleared once the delivery of the event data payload is complete

6024.title: Event Code
6024.description: Event Code is a read-only resource used as an identifier to represent this class of event. The allocation of event codes is implementation specific but ideally be unique across the implementation. Event Codes use vendor specific LogClass value 100...255

When no new data exists, an empty Opaque value should be provided.

The payload data can be provided in an implementation specific serialisation, but by default for fixed length values should use the OMA-LwM2M CBOR format encoded with one of these schemes:-

Event Type = Alarm Current State (1)

In this mode, only the current alarm state should be reported

1. 8-bit integer, value 2 representing OMA-LwM2M CBOR format.
2. Event Code [16-bit integer]
3. Event Type [8-bit Integer] - Alarm Current State (1)
4. Alarm Timestamp [32-bit unsigned integer] representing the number of seconds since Jan 1st, 1970 in the UTC time zone.
5. Alarm State [8-bit Integer]

10278.title: High Temperature Alarm
10278.description: Where supported by the meter this is an alarm that should be raised if the meter detects temperature above a pre-configured threshold. When the temperature drops below the clear threshold, the alarm should be cleared. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

When the temperature drops below the clear threshold, the alarm should be cleared. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

10280.title: Water Network Leak Alarm
10280.description: All meters must support the following default configuration. This alarm will be based on the frequency output of the vibration sensor/accelerometer on the SEW Daughter board. When a frequency is identified that has the characteristics of an upstream network leak, and its amplitude is above the defined threshold, the meter will report this as a network leak alarm. LWM2MVersion: 1.0 ObjectVersion: 1.0 MultipleInstances: true Mandatory: false

6015.title: Alarm Set Operator
6015.description:
Set Operator is a readable and writable resource used in conjunction with the Set Threshold to represent when an alarm is triggered. This resource should be set to one of the following values:-
0. Greater Than or Equal to
1. Less Than or Equal to 
By setting the Set Operator to Greater Than (0), when the measured value for this event exceeds the Set Threshold resource, the event is considered to be in an Alarm State of 1
By setting the Set Operator to Less Than (1), when the measured value for this event falls below the Set Threshold resource, the event is considered to be in an Alarm State of 1

6025.title: Latest Payload
6025.description:
The Latest Eventlog Payload resource is a read-only serialised Opaque (Binary) representation of all the Event Data between the Last Delivered Event Time and the Latest Recorded Event Time. When no new data exists, an empty Opaque value should be provided.

The payload data can be provided in an implementation specific serialisation, but by default for fixed length values should use the OMA-LwM2M CBOR format encoded with one of these schemes:-

Event Type = Alarm Current State (1)

In this mode, only the current alarm state should be reported

1. 8-bit integer, value 2 representing OMA-LwM2M CBOR format.
2. Event Code [16-bit integer]
3. Event Type [8-bit Integer] - Alarm Current State (1)
4. Alarm Timestamp [32-bit unsigned integer] representing the number of seconds since Jan 1st, 1970 in the UTC time zone.
5. Alarm State [8-bit Integer]

6011.description:
Event Type is a readable and writable resource used to represent how this event will behave. Event Type should be one of the following values:-
0. Disabled
1. Alarm Current State
2. Alarm State Change Log
3. Event Log

When the Event Type is set to Disabled (0), this event will not be recorded by the device. No Latest Eventlog payload should be delivered for events that are Disabled.
When the Event Type is set to Alarm Current State (1), this Event is treated as an alarm state manager and the Latest Eventlog Payload will only contain the current state of this alarm.
When the Event Type is set to Alarm State Change Log (2), the Event is treated as an alarm that reports whenever the Alarm is either set or cleared. The Latest Eventlog Payload will contain all alarm transitions since the previous delivery in this mode.
When the Event Type is set to Event Log (3), this object instance is treated as a raw event log. It is used to manage and deliver events. The Latest Eventlog Payload will contain all events since the previous delivery in this mode.

See the Event Log Payload for examples of each of these modes.
